Empires & Puzzles Grendel Hero Review: The Beowulf Brute

Is Grendel the green monster your roster needs? We break down this fast-mana brute from the Beowulf family who brings Elemental Defense Down, nasty bleeds, and a surprising amount of self-sustain to the battlefield. Find out if he is still a top-tier contender.
Grendel: The Sword-Breaking Hell-Brute Smashing Nature's Limits

Grendel bursts onto the scene as a 5-star Nature hero from the Beowulf family, originally released in February 2025. He fills the aggressive role of a fast-mana damage dealer who specializes in softening up targets for a green stack wipeout. As a Monk, he has a knack for resisting ailments, but his true calling is tearing through enemy defenses - specifically their resistance against Nature attacks. While he might look like a chaotic monster who just woke up on the wrong side of the fen, his kit is surprisingly focused and disciplined, revolving around the potent Elemental Defense Down (EDD). He brings the "smash first, ask questions later" mentality that green teams often lack outside of sniper setups.

Visually, Grendel is a lot to take in, in the best way possible. He is a hulking green mass of muscle with wild red hair, looking like he is midway through a very bad day and about to make it everyone else's problem. The art style captures the savage, primal nature of the Beowulf mythology. He is decked out with skulls and ropes, suggesting he is not big on modern fashion but very big on trophies. The dynamic pose, with claws reaching out, gives a real sense of imminent violence. It is definitely one of the more "monster-forward" designs, leaning away from the noble elven warriors or knights we often see in the Nature element.

When we look at Grendel's stats in the context of late 2025, we can see the inevitable march of power creep. With a base power of 1183 and Limit Broken (LB2) power hitting 1430, he sits comfortably in the "strong modern" category, though he is no longer at the bleeding edge.
Compared to the absolute latest heroes released in December 2025, who are pushing 1520+ power and 1600+ attack stats, Grendel is slightly behind the curve. His LB2 attack of 1496 is respectable but not chart-topping anymore. However, his stat distribution is well-balanced. He is not a glass cannon, thanks to decent defense and health pools, which is crucial because his self-sustain requires him to stay alive long enough for the Heal over Time to tick. He remains competitive, but he relies more on his special skill utility than raw stat dominance.

Gruesome Charge is a textbook example of a high-utility fast skill. The order of operations here is what makes Grendel excellent.
First, he applies the

to the target and nearby enemies. This is critical. It means the subsequent damage portion of his skill (320%) immediately benefits from this reduction, hitting significantly harder than the percentage suggests.
Second, the

(591 over 3 turns) adds a layer of inevitability to his pressure. Bleed is particularly annoying because it often bypasses certain defensive buffs or minion protections depending on the specific mechanics of the era.
Third, the
(810 HP over 3 turns) turns him into a surprisingly durable bruiser. While it does not help his teammates, it ensures that your primary defense breaker stays on the field to fire again.

Compared to older EDD heroes like Evelyn or Almur, Grendel offers significantly more damage and survivability. He is the modern standard for this archetype, combining the utility of a support hero with the damage output of a striker.
Let's break down the math to see what Grendel really brings to the table.
Fast. He needs 8 tiles to charge, or 7 with a level 29 mana troop (or appropriate bard/family bonuses). This break point is essential for 3-stacking in wars.
320% damage to 3 targets is a total of 960% damage output. However, because the Elemental Defense Down applies
the hit, the effective damage is roughly equivalent to a hero hitting for ~450% on neutral defense targets.
591 Bleed over 3 turns is 197 damage per turn per enemy. Across 3 enemies, that is nearly 1800 guaranteed damage if not cleansed.
270 HP recovered per turn for 3 turns. This is roughly 10-12% of his max HP per turn, providing a steady stream of recovery that mitigates slash attacks and DoT.
Family Bonus, Passives, Aether Power & Unique Abilities
Grendel's kit is rounded out by a set of passives and bonuses that specifically address common counters to fast heroes.

The Beowulf family bonus provides a chance to cleanse status ailments from all allies when the hero receives special skill damage. For a hero like Grendel who might be placed in a flank position, this is a nice safety net. While you shouldn't rely on it as your primary cleanse, it can ruin an opponent's setup if they try to soften you up with ailment-heavy openers.
These passives are where Grendel truly shines in the meta:
This is a hard counter to Blind (Drake Fong, Justice) and Dodge (C. Kadilen, Xiaosi). Grendel will always land his EDD and damage, ensuring your combo doesn't break because of a lucky dodge.
This is massive. Heroes like Waterpipe, Xiahou Dun, or the countless mana-cutting tanks cannot stop Grendel. Not only does he resist it, but he effectively
the enemy by gaining boosted health and mana.
Getting hit makes him stronger. In a prolonged fight, Grendel can ramp up his attack significantly, making his second or third fire devastating.

is a simple, effective choice for a damage dealer. It boosts his base attack for the first 6 turns, which aligns perfectly with his Fast speed. You want him to fire early and hard to secure a kill, and this Aether Power facilitates exactly that.

Upon his release in early 2025, Grendel was hailed as the "Evelyn on steroids." Nature teams had been starving for a modern, hitting EDD hero who could survive the harsh rigorous of the meta. He immediately replaced older options in top-tier titan teams and war attack squads.

By the end of 2025, Grendel's stats have been surpassed by the "Titan Hunter" and "Three Kingdoms" waves. However, his utility (Fast EDD) is timeless. Elemental Defense Down is one of the few mechanics that resists power creep because it scales with the strength of your other heroes. As long as you have strong green snipers or AOE hitters, Grendel acts as a force multiplier.

Grendel remains highly viable. He is a staple in green stacks for wars and indispensable for Blue Titans. While he may not be the terrifying tank or flank he was on day one, he is a premier offensive support hero who can hold his own.
As a Monk, Grendel has the chance to resist status ailments, which adds another layer of reliability.
Maximizes the damage of his initial hit and the bleed damage (if based on attack stats). Ensures that when he breaks defense, he also contributes significant kill pressure.
Slightly lower survivability, relying on his self-heal to stay afloat.
Keeps him alive longer to benefit from his stacking attack passive and self-heal. Better if you use him on defense.
Reduces the impact of his special skill's direct damage, turning him into more of a pure utility support.
path is recommended. Grendel's job is to kill things fast. His defensive passives and self-heal cover his survival needs adequately, so you should go all-in on making his punch hurt.
The single most valuable offensive debuff for maximizing tile and special damage.
Perfect Accuracy and Mana Reduction Resistance make him incredibly reliable. He fires when you need him to, and he hits what you aim at.
He heals himself and ramps up his own attack, requiring less babysitting than older glass cannons.
hitting is a massive damage optimizer.
While great for him, he offers no survival support to his teammates.
In formations where enemies are spread out (like Double formations), his efficacy drops as he can't hit the whole team.
Newer heroes simply have bigger numbers, meaning his direct damage might not secure kills on full-health modern tanks without help.
Absolute top tier. Fast EDD is non-negotiable for high scores against Blue Titans.
Excellent in a 3-2 or 4-1 green stack. Pair him with a slower, heavy hitter to wipe a side.
Great for picking apart defenses. His accuracy helps counter the dodge meta often found in raid defenses.
Grendel fires first, dropping defense. Two snipers (like C. Lianna or similar modern equivalents) follow up on the debuffed targets for guaranteed kills.
Grendel - Tarlak/Bertulf (Attack Up) - Ratatoskr (Tile Buff) - Franz (Damage Inc) -
Standard titan maximizing. Grendel provides the specific defense down component.
Heroes like Garnet or Hathor who block status ailments prevent his EDD and Bleed, neutering his damage potential.
War Equalizer or fast cleansers can remove the EDD before you can capitalize on it with tiles.
Do not pair him with Almur or Evelyn unless you are very desperate. The debuffs overwrite each other rather than stacking, wasting a slot.

If you are lucky enough to pull Grendel early, he is a game-changer. Prioritize leveling him immediately. He will carry your green team through map stages and allow you to punch way above your weight class in raids by enabling your other green heroes to do massive damage. Do not worry too much about perfect emblems yet; just get him maxed and enjoying the damage boost.

You likely have older EDD options. Grendel replaces them. He is worth the tonics and the limit break purely for the stats survival upgrade over someone like Evelyn. However, consider carefully before investing Alpha Aethers. While his Aether power is good, he is a utility hero. If you have the latest 2026-ready monster damage dealer, they might benefit more from the LB2 stats than Grendel, whose main job is just to land the debuff.
When Grendel was first previewed in beta, the community reaction was overwhelmingly positive but tempered with comparisons.
One player noted, "Basically a modern version of Pophit... but still super strong regardless, this is definitely the one I’d want from this portal."

There was some debate about his damage output, with one user complaining, "Why this hero hit is so weak when he only do damage to three targets only?" to which others correctly replied, "Because it has priority defence down so it’s a much bigger hit than it looks."
The "Maxibon" comparison from the S Show became a niche meme - solid, reliable, and tasty, even if not the fanciest dessert on the menu.
His resistance to mana reduction was highlighted as a key selling point against the specific "mana control" meta dominant at his release.

Grendel is the gym buddy who spots you on the bench press - he does the heavy lifting so you (and your other heroes) can look good. He brings a vital utility kit packaged in a modern, durable frame that fixes the fragility issues of his predecessors. While he lacks the flash of a team-wide wipeout button, his contribution to the overall damage output of a green stack is immeasurable. He is a workhorse, a brute, and exactly the kind of monster you want on your side of the battlefield.
Is he the strongest hero ever released? No. But is he the one you will use every single day on Titans and Wars for the next two years? Absolutely.
